bibl.title: Notes on Marie D. Gorgas' manuscript by [Henry Rose Carter], [1923]

div1.p: [Carter] gives corrections on a manuscript. He comments extensively on Gorgas, Havana around 1900, Finlay, his own work on extrinsic incubation and its influence on Reed, and the immediate influence of Reed's work

div1.head: Notes on Marie D. Gorgas' manuscript by [Henry Rose Carter], [1923]
div1.p: Mem.
Page 1: Status of Gorgas in Habana.

When I first met Gorgas in Havana, in January /99, hashe was reporting to
General Brooks, Governor General of the Island, and could scarcely have
been Chief Sanitary Officer of the City of Havana, of which General Ludlow
was Military Governor. A Dr. Davis--a Contract Surgeon from Illinois--
was at this time doing the sanitary work in Havana. I came often in
contact, and sometimes in conflict, with him and his gangs on the water-
front.

Davis reported to Ludlow and was regarded, by Gorgas and myself, as
as his “man - Friday.” He left the Service in May, or possibly very early
June and Gorgas succeeded him--reporting then to Ludlow. I then met
him (Gorgas) and his gangs (but without conflict) on the water-front.

Gorgas waived his claim to a higher position (both places becoming
vacant at about the same time) in favor of Major Kean and took this
one. He did this because Kean did not wish to do yellow fever sanitary
work and Gorgas did.

Gorgas had been Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana some time Reed came
down. The sanitary work then done in the winter and spring of /99--
mainly with Electrozone etc.--was by Davis. Gorgas must have begun in
May or very early June the same year. I do not know that any sanitary
work against yellow fever was done in /98. If so, I judge it was done
by Davis.

First called “Yellow Fever,” so far as I can find, in 1750
Pag 1 (A) - by Griffitts Hughes in Nat. History of Barbados & of no importance.

Page 20: (30)--“when a man developed yellow fever aboard ship that none

him to believe that yellow fever could not be contracted from the environment
of a sick man for a considerable time after he became sick in it.”

Please insert the above in place of “a considerable time--his own
sickness.” It better expresses what was observed.

Page 20: (31)--Please insert: “finally obtained sufficient data to
feel that its publication would be convincing to others” in place of: “sub-

He had been working on this matter, as occasion offered, since 1888
and convinced of the doctrine, as stated above, since 1893, but could con-
vince no one else whose opinion he valued.

Carter thus formulated it: “When a man developed yel-
low fever in a clean but infectable environment, this environment became in-
fected at once--within a few hours--but did not become infective--i. e. cap-
capable of producing yellow fever in other men, until a considerable period
of time had elapsed.” This period of time he called the “period of extrinsic
incubation of yellow fever” and later determined it tentatively as “minimally
somewhat in excess of ten days.”

This is, I think, correct and might be substituted for part of the
of the MSS between AA and BB, Page 21 (MSS), which does not seem to be en-
tirely so--e. g. “evidently the yellow fever patient was not a menace to his
environment when he first fell ill.”

Page 21: (33) The sick man was dangerous to his environment (in-
fecting it) when he first became ill. He was at no time directly a danger
ger to people. Even his environment was not a danger to them until “somewhat
over 10 days” after the beginning of his sickness in it. The danger to well
well
-6-
people in the infected environment was, as you say, independent of the sick
man's continued presence. This last, of course, had been known for years,
but not that the environment was not dangerous from the beginning of his
sickness in it. The essence of Carter's discovery was the existence of the
period of extrinsic incubation (during which the environment although infected
was not infective).

Page 21: (33')--Is this sentence correct? “The sick man was dangerous” etc.
(See Page 5 (Notes) Page 21: (33)--MSS)
Page 21: (34)--“dates,” not “figures,” was the word Reed used.

Page 22: (35)--Considering the data in Carter's paper with the then
recent work of Ronald Ross on the transmission of malaria their meaning was
at once clear to Reed.

Ross had shown that an Anopheles mosquito feeding on men sick of mal-
aria took the organisms of malaria into her stomach and that these organ-
isms underwent a special developement in her body. After this developement
is complete, and not until then, the developed organism can be conveyed to
a well man by the mosquito biting him.

Ross had also shown, and emphasized, that this developement required
time. In fact it usually takes (in hot weather) about 11 days from the in-
fecting feeding for the full developement of the malaria organism in the
mosquito and for her to become infective. Until this developement of the
organism is complete she cannot convey malaria.

Reed then had made the deduction that the explanation of Carter's
findings was that the mechanism of the transmission of yellow fever from
man to man was similar to that of malaria: Ross' mosquitoes were in-
fected as soon as they had bitten a man sick of malari, but not infective
to other men until after the full developement of the malarial organism in
their bodies had taken place, which required considerable time: Carter's
“environment” became infected “at once, within a few hours,” when a case
of yellow fever developed in it, but not “infective” to other men until a
a
-7-
considerable time had elapsed--the “period of extrinsic incubation of
yellow fever.” WasCould the infection of the “environment to be due to infected mos-
quitoes” in it! (The parallelism between these, phenomena seemed very close.

Reed's immediate deduction then was that the organism of yellow fever was
taken into the body of some suctorial insect., probably by its feeding on
a man sick of that disease, and underwent a special developement in the
body of that insect after which (and only after which) it could be con-
veyed to a well man (by the insect feeding on him) producing the dis-
ease in him and that this developement required time--represented by
Carter's period of extrinsic incubation. (corresponding to the 11 days for malaria) That the time elapsing between
the developement of the disease in Carter's houses by the men who in-
fected them and the dates the houses acquired the power of transmitting
the disease (“period of extrinsic incubation of yellow fever”) represented
the time necessary for the developement of the organism to take place in
the body of the insect which, until this was completed, was not infective
to man. During this time the houses might harbor any number of infected
insects, not yet infective, and hence as yet incapable of transmitting yel-
low fever, but which in time, at the end of the period of extrinsic in-
cubation, would become infective to man and dangerous.

Page 22: (36)-- Is this correct? The organism, once ingested, re-
mains in the infected insect's body indefinitely: we believe all her life--
certainly for 57 days in one instance.

From Page 27: (XX) to Page 28: (YY)-- All of this is true, but no
one appreciated the difficulty of eliminating yellow fever by isolation
of men sick of it from mosquitoes and killing those in the house which
may have fed on them (control of the human host) until we tried it in
Panama and found it to fail. Both methods of attack (control of the
human host and that of the insect host as well) were, as you state, used in
Havana, but the main stress was laid on the control of the human host
(isolation etc. of sick man) and the destruction of Stegomyia breeding
places, although well done, was regarded rather as an adjuvant to the
main attack. I am afraid that you have rather given the reverse impres-
sion. We did not (any of us) recognize the comparative efficacy of
these contrasting methods until after eighteen months experience in
Panama.

Page 27: (Y)-- Your meaning is to me clear and what you mean is cor-
rect--i. e. that there are many cases of yellow fever not easily diag-
nosticated--especially in young children babies & negroes In young negro babies -- diagnosis
would in general be. to me, impossible except from the conditions un-
der which the disease occurred. I think however, that the characterization
tic of yellow fever as “preeminently a disease of the walking variety”
would be very generally rejected by Southern practitioners familiar with
with

it. There are walking cases--that generally die--but most cases (prac-
tically all those recognized) among adult whites and in whites near
puberty, go down like a shot from the first. I know of no other dis-
ease generally as sudden and severe in onset, save dengue.

In Panama, undertaken just afterwards, he mainly depended on empty-

Oiling is less efficient against Stegomyia than any mosquito I know except

of which they were extremely prompt to avail themselves. They were
handled easily, as they wanted to enter hospital if yellow fever were

Page 37: (c)--This may well have been, and probably was, the popular
opinion, and we, of course, knew less of herits biology than we do now,
but Finlay's selection of this mosquito as the vector of yellow fever
was primarily on account of herits being a “house mosquito.”

Page 38: (d)-- Noble's statement in pencil here is correct. This
epidemic was eliminated by sanitary measures similar to those in 1900.

Page 40: (e)-- The entomological name of the yellow fever carrying
mosquito (U. S. Bureau of Entomology) is Aëdes (Stegomyia) aegypti, but
as this is the only member of this sub-genus found in the Americas it is
usually called simply “Stegomyia” by American writers. I, however, have
called it “aegypti..” in

Reed's findings were accepted promptly by scientific men, and
not only the findings themselves, but their practical application as
well. The requirements of the Maritime Quarantine of the U. S. were modi-
fied that spring (1900) to conform thereto: Of those of the State Quaran-
tines some changed at once, and all within a short time, to the same end.
Ribas and de Sousa of Sao Paolo, Brazil, began work against yellow fever
in Santos, based solely on Stegomyia conveyance, also in 1900, using
practically the same methods Gorgas used in Habana. Liceaga soon after-
wards began work in Vera Cruz, by the same methods and for the same pur-
pose, as did Oswaldo Cruz in Rio de Janeiro.

Such prompt, one one may immediate, acceptance of a medical
discovery had not been usual, but Reed's experiments had been complete
and convincing and the clinching of the matter by the elimination of yel-
low fever from Habana left no room for cavil.
